topic: 7 AI agents that replaced my content team

thread.text:
I replaced my entire content team with 7 AI agents.

Here's exactly what each one does:

First: I'm not doing this to be cheap. I'm doing it because I was burning 6 hours a day on content scaffolding.

I'm an operator. Not a content creator. The agents freed me to run my actual business.

Agent 1: The Orchestrator.

Every morning at 2am it scrapes Reddit, pulls trending signals, and packages a briefing. By 7am I have a prioritized list of what to talk about. I never start with a blank page.
thread.image_concept: Screenshot of the 2am briefing output, trending topics highlighted

thread.text:
Agent 2: The Thread Writer.

Knows my voice rules, my past posts, my positioning. It drafts thread options from the morning briefing. I review, tweak maybe 20%, approve. What used to take 2 hours takes 10 minutes.

Agent 3: The Carousel Builder.

Input: a core idea. Output: slide-by-slide copy, hooks, CTA, formatted. I hand it off for design or build it myself in Canva. The copy is done before I open a single tool.

Agent 4: The Research Agent.

Before anything goes live, it checks what I've posted in the last 30 days. No topic cannibalization. No accidental repeats. It's the memory I don't have the bandwidth to keep manually.

Agent 5: The Publisher.

Schedules posts across X and LinkedIn. Knows not to post back-to-back. Knows which time windows hit. I set the queue on Monday and don't touch it again.

Agent 6: The Engagement Monitor.

Watches for comments and threads worth joining. Surfaces them with context, the angle to take, the opening line. I stopped doomscrolling. I review a curated list instead.

Agent 7: The Lead Magnet Builder.

Takes top-performing content and repurposes it into PDFs, frameworks, and downloads. My Skool community gets new resources every week. I didn't write a single one from scratch.

Total monthly cost: under $30 in API fees.

Time saved: 30-40 hours a week.

I built the system once. It runs on its own. That's the only kind of automation worth building.

The thing people get wrong: they think AI removes you from your content.

It doesn't. I'm still the voice. I still make every call. The agents just handle the scaffolding so I can focus on the 10% that actually needs me.

The framework I used to build all of this is called B.U.I.L.D.

It's what turned a collection of agents into an actual system.

Comment 'AI' and I'll send it to you.
